questions.question: In the Working Stress Method, what is the primary purpose of the modular ratio, 'm'?

answerOptions.text: To account for the difference in the modulus of elasticity between steel and concrete.
To apply a factor of safety to the material strengths.
To determine the ultimate load-carrying capacity of the section.
To calculate the effects of long-term creep in concrete.

questions.question: Why is the permissible compressive stress in bending ($\sigma_{cbc}$) for concrete higher than the permissible stress in direct compression ($\sigma_{cc}$)?

answerOptions.text: Because the stress distribution in bending is triangular, not uniform.
Because bending loads are always smaller than direct compression loads.
Because the presence of steel reinforcement helps carry the compressive load.
Because concrete is inherently stronger in bending than in direct compression.

questions.question: An under-reinforced section in WSM is designed such that:

answerOptions.text: Steel reaches its permissible stress before concrete.
Concrete reaches its permissible stress before steel.
Both steel and concrete reach their permissible stresses simultaneously.
The depth of the actual neutral axis is greater than the critical neutral axis.

questions.question: What is the concept of a 'transformed section' used for in WSM analysis?

answerOptions.text: To analyze a reinforced concrete section as if it were made of a single, homogeneous material.
To increase the calculated moment of inertia of the section.
To account for the non-linear stress-strain behavior of concrete.
To calculate the shear stress distribution in the beam.

questions.question: Which of the following is a significant limitation of the Working Stress Method?

answerOptions.text: It does not provide a realistic measure of the structure's true factor of safety against collapse.
It results in very thin and uneconomical sections compared to the Limit State Method.
It cannot be used for the design of water tanks or other serviceability-critical structures.
It ignores the tensile strength of concrete.

questions.question: In WSM, if the actual neutral axis depth ($x$) is less than the critical neutral axis depth ($x_c$), the section is classified as:

answerOptions.text: Under-reinforced
Over-reinforced
Balanced
Critically-reinforced

questions.question: The Factor of Safety in WSM is applied by:

answerOptions.text: Dividing the material's yield/ultimate strength by a factor to get permissible stress.
Multiplying the working loads by a factor to get the design load.
Ensuring the strain in concrete does not exceed a specific limit.
Using a lower value for the modulus of elasticity of concrete.

questions.question: A key assumption of WSM, which is also shared by LSM, is:

answerOptions.text: A plane section before bending remains plane after bending.
The stress-strain curve for concrete is parabolic.
Partial safety factors are applied to loads and materials.
The design is based on the collapse state of the structure.

questions.question: In an over-reinforced section designed by WSM, what is the mode of failure?

answerOptions.text: Sudden crushing of concrete in the compression zone.
Gradual yielding of steel in the tension zone.
Simultaneous crushing of concrete and yielding of steel.
Shear failure before flexural failure.

questions.question: In WSM, when is compression reinforcement in a doubly reinforced beam considered?

answerOptions.text: When the applied bending moment exceeds the moment of resistance of a balanced section for the given dimensions.
In all T-beams and L-beams.
When using mild steel (Fe 250) instead of high-yield strength steel.
To ensure the section is always under-reinforced.

questions.question: The term 'lever arm' in WSM refers to the distance between:

answerOptions.text: The resultant compressive force and the resultant tensile force.
The extreme compression fiber and the centroid of the tension steel.
The neutral axis and the centroid of the tension steel.
The extreme compression fiber and the neutral axis.

questions.question: How does the Working Stress Method account for different types of loads like Dead Load (DL) and Live Load (LL)?

answerOptions.text: It treats all loads the same and does not apply different factors of safety to them.
It applies a higher factor of safety to Live Loads than to Dead Loads.
It uses different permissible stresses depending on the load combination.
It analyzes the structure separately for Dead Load and Live Load.

questions.question: The formula for the critical neutral axis depth ($x_c$) in WSM depends on:

answerOptions.text: The modular ratio and the effective depth.
The area of steel provided and the width of the beam.
The applied bending moment only.
The grade of concrete only.

questions.question: Which statement best reflects the economic implications of WSM?

answerOptions.text: It generally leads to larger and heavier sections compared to LSM.
It is more economical because it uses simpler calculations.
It allows for higher stresses in steel, making it more efficient.
It has no significant economic difference from the Limit State Method.

questions.question: The design philosophy of WSM is most suitable for which of the following design criteria?

answerOptions.text: Serviceability criteria like crack control and deflection.
Ultimate strength and collapse prevention.
Earthquake and seismic design.
Probabilistic assessment of structural safety.
